title: 110_hr3820
content: The Act may be cited as the "Commercial Motor Vehicle Advanced Safety Technology Tax Act of 2007". Congress finds that commercial motor vehicle crashes are a major concern in the United States, especially with the increasing number of trucks and their role in transporting hazardous materials. A 2004 report showed that crashes involving large trucks are 2.6 times more likely to result in fatalities compared to passenger cars. In 2005, 5,212 individuals died and 114,000 were injured in large truck-related crashes in the US. Large truck-related crashes in the United States resulted in 5,212 deaths and 114,000 injuries in 2005. From 2001 to 2005, there were a total of 25,533 fatalities. These crashes also have a significant economic impact, costing society $230.6 billion annually. The estimated cost of each crash involving a large truck is $91,112, with fatal crashes averaging $3,604,518. The estimated cost of crashes involving trucks over 10,000 pounds is $91,112, with fatal crashes averaging $3,604,518. Investments in advanced safety technologies aim to reduce traffic fatalities. The Department of Transportation aims to lower the traffic fatality rate by 2011. Accelerated deployment of safety technologies on commercial vehicles is crucial. The accelerated deployment of advanced safety technologies on commercial motor vehicles is crucial to reducing traffic fatalities and injuries on the nation's roads. Congress aims to increase the deployment of these technologies by providing tax incentives to businesses, making the systems more affordable for purchase. SEC. 3. CREDIT FOR ADVANCED COMMERCIAL VEHICLE SAFETY SYSTEMS. This section adds a new credit for commercial vehicle advanced safety systems to the Internal Revenue Code, aiming to increase the deployment of these technologies by providing tax incentives to businesses. The new credit for commercial vehicle advanced safety systems under section 38 allows a 50% credit for the cost of qualified systems placed in service during the taxable year. Limitations include a maximum credit of $1,500 per system and $3,500 per vehicle, with adjustments for prior credits claimed by the taxpayer. The new credit for commercial vehicle advanced safety systems under section 38 allows a 50% credit for the cost of qualified systems placed in service during the taxable year. The credit allowable to the taxpayer for the taxable year shall not exceed $350,000. A qualified commercial vehicle advanced safety system includes brake stroke monitoring, lane departure warning, collision warning, or vehicle stability systems identified by the Federal Motor Carrier Safety Administration or the National Highway Administrator. The new credit for commercial vehicle advanced safety systems under section 38 allows a 50% credit for qualified systems enhancing safety or security. The system must be certified by the manufacturer and appropriate for the vehicle model before use. The new credit for commercial vehicle advanced safety systems under section 38 allows a 50% credit for qualified systems enhancing safety or security. The system must be appropriate for the make, type, and model of the qualified commercial vehicle, function as designed if installed properly, certified by the installer if not installed by the manufacturer, and the original use of the system begins with the taxpayer. The new credit for commercial vehicle advanced safety systems under section 38 allows a 50% credit for qualified systems enhancing safety or security. The system must be properly installed and functioning on the vehicle before first use by the taxpayer, and depreciation is allowable. A qualified commercial vehicle is defined as a highway motor vehicle used for commerce with a gross weight rating of 26,001 pounds or more. The new credit for commercial vehicle advanced safety systems under section 38 allows a 50% credit for qualified systems enhancing safety or security. A qualified commercial vehicle is defined as a highway motor vehicle used for commerce with a gross weight rating of 26,001 pounds or more, and specific criteria are outlined for vehicles with certain seating capacities or expected uses. The curr_chunk defines terms related to safety systems for commercial vehicles, including brake stroke monitoring system and lane departure warning system. Brake stroke monitoring system uses electronic sensors to detect brake issues, while lane departure warning system alerts drivers of lane deviations or blind spot obstacles. The curr_chunk defines terms for safety systems in commercial vehicles, including collision warning and vehicle stability systems that alert drivers of potential collisions and intervene in rollover risks. The curr_chunk discusses how safety systems in commercial vehicles automatically intervene in rollover or directional instability situations by reducing speed or applying brakes. Additionally, it defines controlled groups for tax purposes and special rules for property basis reduction. In applying section 52 to this section, section 1563 shall be applied without regard to subsection (b)(2)(C). Special rules include basis reduction for property with allowable credits, recapture of credits, and disqualification of credits for property used outside the United States. No credit allowed under subsection (a) for property in section 50(b)(1) or cost of property under section 179. For qualified commercial vehicle advanced safety systems used by tax-exempt entities, the seller must disclose any allowable credit without section 38(c) to the buyer. No credit allowed under subsection (a) for qualified commercial vehicle advanced safety systems if taxpayer elects not to apply this section. Supporting documentation required for credit approval. No credit allowed under subsection (a) for qualified commercial vehicle advanced safety systems unless the owner provides required documentation, including system type, purchase date, and certification. The credit for qualified commercial vehicle advanced safety systems requires documentation including system type, purchase date, and certification. This section does not apply to property placed in service after December 31, 2012. The credit is part of the general business credit. The tax code was amended to include a new paragraph (32) for the commercial vehicle advanced safety system credit. Conforming amendments were made to sections 1016(a) and 6501(m) of the Code. The tax code was amended to include a new paragraph for the commercial vehicle advanced safety system credit. Subsection (m) of section 6501 was also amended to include additional references. The tax code was amended to include a credit for commercial vehicle advanced safety systems, effective for property placed in service after the enactment of the Act.
